sen.j: 圓證寺（えんしょうじ）は、奈良県生駒市にある真言律宗の寺院。
sen.e: Ensho-ji Temple is a Shingon Risshu Sect Buddhist temple located in Ikoma City, Nara Prefecture.
Ensho-ji Temple is a Buddhist temple of the Shingon Ritsu sect located in Ikoma City, Nara Prefecture.
Ensho-ji Temple is a Buddhist temple of the Shingon Ritsu sect located in Ikoma City, Nara Prefecture.

sen.j: 山号はなし。
sen.e: The temple has no honorific mountain prefix.
It does not have a sango (literally, "mountain name"), which is the title prefixed to the name of a Buddhist temple.
sen.cmt: 統一用語を使用（山号）しました。
sen.e: It does not have a sango (literally, "mountain name"), which is the title prefixed to the name of a Buddhist temple.

sen.j: 本尊は釈迦如来。
sen.e: Its principal image is Shaka Nyorai (Shakyamuni Tathagata).
The principal image of Buddha is Shaka Nyorai (Shakyamuni Tathagata)
The principal image of Buddha is Shaka Nyorai (Shakyamuni Tathagata)

sen.j: 戦国大名筒井氏ゆかりの寺院である。
sen.e: The temple is remembered in connection with the Tsutsui clan, a Sengoku warlord.
This temple is remembered in connection with the Tsutsui clan, one of Sengoku daimyo (Japanese territorial loads in the Sengoku period) families.
sen.cmt: 「戦国大名」に用語集上の訳を採用しました。
sen.e: This temple is remembered in connection with the Tsutsui clan, one of Sengoku daimyo (Japanese territorial loads in the Sengoku period) families.

sen.j: 歴史
sen.e: History
History
History

sen.j: 圓證寺は大和国の戦国大名・筒井家ゆかりの寺院である。
sen.e: Ensho-ji Temple is a temple that is remembered in connection with the Tsutsui family, a Sengoku warlord in Yamatonokuni Province.
Ensho-ji Temple is a temple associated with the Tsutsui clan, a Sengoku daimyo family in Yamato Province.
sen.cmt: 統一用語に従い変更（大和国）しました。表現も変更しました。
sen.e: Ensho-ji Temple is a temple associated with the Tsutsui clan, a Sengoku daimyo family in Yamato Province.

sen.j: 現在は奈良県生駒市上町の新興住宅街の中にあるが、1985年同地に移転するまでは、近鉄奈良駅近くの奈良市林小路町に所在した。
sen.e: Although the temple is currently situated in a newly developed residential area in Kami-machi, Ikoma City, Nara Prefecture, it was located in Hayashikoji-cho, Nara City, near Kintetsu Nara Station before its relocation to Kami-machi in 1985.

Although the temple is currently situated in a newly developed residential area in Kami-machi, Ikoma City, Nara Prefecture, it was located in Hayashikoji-cho, Nara City, near Kintetsu Nara Station before its relocation to Kami-machi in 1985.

Although the temple is currently situated in a newly developed residential area in Kami-machi, Ikoma City, Nara Prefecture, it was located in Hayashikoji-cho, Nara City, near Kintetsu Nara Station before its relocation to Kami-machi in 1985.

sen.j: 当寺は寛平年間（889 – 897）の創建と伝え、元は筒井氏の本拠地である大和国添下郡筒井（現・大和郡山市）に所在したというが、創建の正確な経緯や中世以前の歴史については定かでない。
sen.e: It is said that this temple was founded during the Kanpyo era (889-897) and was originally located in Tsutsui District, Sofunoshimonokori County, Yamatonokuni Province (today's Yamatokoriyama City), which was the Tsutsui clan's base, but the precise course of events leading to the foundation and its premedieval history have not been confirmed.

It is said that this temple was founded during the Kanpyo era (889-897) and originally located in Tsutsui, Sofunoshimo County, Yamato Province (today's Yamatokoriyama City), which was the Tsutsui clan's base, but the precise details of the foundation and its pre-medieval history have not been confirmed.
sen.cmt: 筒井は後の文でvillageとなっているので、ここではTsutsuiのみ残します。指示書に従い地名表現を変更しました。
sen.e: It is said that this temple was founded during the Kanpyo era (889-897) and originally located in Tsutsui, Sofunoshimo County, Yamato Province (today's Yamatokoriyama City), which was the Tsutsui clan's base, but the precise details of the foundation and its pre-medieval history have not been confirmed.

sen.j: 筒井氏の起源については必ずしも明らかではないが、大和国の土豪であり、中世には興福寺の衆徒（しゅと）であった。
sen.e: The origin of the Tsutsui clan is not necessarily clear, but they were a local clan in Yamatonokuni Province and were warrior priests (shuto) of Kofuku-ji Temple in the middle ages.
The origin of the Tsutsui clan is not perfectly clear, but it is known that they were a local clan in Yamato Province and were the shuto (monk-soldiers) of Kofuku-ji Temple in the middle ages.
sen.cmt: 語の使用に不自然な印象を受けたので言葉を変え、文の意味が通るように言葉を補いました。指示書に従い地名表現を変更しました。
sen.e: The origin of the Tsutsui clan is not perfectly clear, but it is known that they were a local clan in Yamato Province and were the shuto (monk-soldiers) of Kofuku-ji Temple in the middle ages.

sen.j: 興福寺は中世には大和一国を支配する大勢力であり、衆徒とは同寺に仕えた法体の武士で、「僧兵」とほぼ同義である。
sen.e: Kofuku-ji Temple was a powerhouse holding sway over the entire province of Yamantonokuni, and 'shuto,' referring to samurai warriors serving Kofuku-ji Temple, is almost synonymous with 'sohei' (monk-soldiers).

Kofuku-ji Temple was a powerhouse holding sway over the entire province of Yamanto in medieval times, and the word 'shuto' refers to samurai warriors dressed like Buddhist priests who served Kofuku-ji Temple and is almost synonymous with 'sohei (priest soldiers)'.
sen.cmt: 訳漏れあり（中世に、法体の）、補いました。
sen.e: Kofuku-ji Temple was a powerhouse holding sway over the entire province of Yamanto in medieval times, and the word 'shuto' refers to samurai warriors dressed like Buddhist priests who served Kofuku-ji Temple and is almost synonymous with 'sohei (priest soldiers)'.

sen.j: 筒井家は興福寺にほど近い林小路（現在の奈良市林小路町）にも外館（下屋敷）を構えていた。
sen.e: The Tsutsui family also had a 'todate' (literally an outer mansion or suburban residence) in Hayashikoji (at present, Hayashikoji-cho, Nara City) near Kofuku-ji Temple.
The Tsutsui family also had a 'todate' (literally an outer mansion or suburban residence) in Hayashikoji (at present, Hayashikoji-cho, Nara City) near Kofuku-ji Temple.
The Tsutsui family also had a 'todate' (literally an outer mansion or suburban residence) in Hayashikoji (at present, Hayashikoji-cho, Nara City) near Kofuku-ji Temple.

sen.j: 戦国大名として著名な筒井順慶（1549 - 1584）の父である筒井順昭（1523 – 1550）が、天文19年（1550年）、林小路の館で死去した後、順昭の夫人が夫の菩提を弔うため、館を寺に改めたという。
sen.e: After Junsho TSUTSUI (1523-1550), the father of Junkei TSUTSUI (1549-1584) well-known as a Sengoku warlord, died in the mansion of Hayashikoji in 1550, Junsho's wife changed the mansion to a temple in order to pray for Buddha for the repose of her husband's soul.

It is said that after Junsho TSUTSUI (1523-1550), the father of a well-known Sengoku warlord, Junkei TSUTSUI (1549-1584), died in the mansion in Hayashikoji in 1550, Junsho's wife remodeled the mansion into a temple in order to pray for Buddha for the repose of her husband's soul.
sen.cmt: 「という」の意が抜けているので、補足しました。Changeをremodelに修正しました。
sen.e: It is said that after Junsho TSUTSUI (1523-1550), the father of a well-known Sengoku warlord, Junkei TSUTSUI (1549-1584), died in the mansion in Hayashikoji in 1550, Junsho's wife remodeled the mansion into a temple in order to pray for Buddha for the repose of her husband's soul.

sen.j: この際に前述の添下郡筒井庄の圓證寺の寺籍が林小路に移されたものと見られる。
sen.e: It is considered that the temple registration of Ensho-ji Temple in aforementioned Tsutsui Village, Sofunoshimonokori County, was transferred on this occasion.

It is considered that the records of Ensho-ji Temple in the temple register that had been registered in the aforementioned location, Tsutsui Village, Sofunoshimo County, was changed into Hayashikoji on this occasion.

It is considered that the records of Ensho-ji Temple in the temple register that had been registered in the aforementioned location, Tsutsui Village, Sofunoshimo County, was changed into Hayashikoji on this occasion.

sen.j: 順昭が28歳の若さで没した際、跡取りの順慶は数え年2歳であったため、順昭の死は伏せられ、順昭と姿格好が似ていた木阿弥（黙阿弥）という盲目の僧が順昭の影武者となった。
sen.e: When Junsho died prematurely at the age of 28, his heir Junkei was two years old by the traditional Japanese system and therefore Junsho's death was kept secret and a blind monk called Mokuami, who resembled Junsho in appearance, served as his body double.

When Junsho died prematurely at the age of 28, his heir, Junkei, was only two years old by the traditional Japanese system and therefore Junsho's death was kept secret and a blind monk called Mokuami, who resembled Junsho in appearance, served as his body double.

When Junsho died prematurely at the age of 28, his heir, Junkei, was only two years old by the traditional Japanese system and therefore Junsho's death was kept secret and a blind monk called Mokuami, who resembled Junsho in appearance, served as his body double.

sen.j: 「元の木阿弥（黙阿弥）」という言葉はここから来ている。
sen.e: The phrase 'Moto no Mokuami' (to lose all that one has gained) derives from this.
The phrase 'Moto no Mokuami' (to lose all that one has gained) derives from this.
The phrase 'Moto no Mokuami' (to lose all that one has gained) derives from this.

sen.j: 林小路町の圓證寺は、現在の近鉄奈良駅南方の繁華街に位置し、ファッションビルの奈良ビブレ付近がその跡地にあたる。
sen.e: Ensho-ji Temple in Hayashikoji-cho is situated in the present downtown area south of Kintetsu Nara Station, and the vicinity of Nara VIVRE, a fashion building, is where the temple used to be.
Ensho-ji Temple was in Hayashikoji-cho, which is now the downtown area south of Kintetsu Nara Station, and the site where the temple used to be is in the vicinity of Nara VIVRE, a department store.
sen.cmt: 時制を変え（寺は今この場所にはないので）、それに伴い表現も変えました。ファッションビルは和製英語だと思ったので、語を変えました。
sen.e: Ensho-ji Temple was in Hayashikoji-cho, which is now the downtown area south of Kintetsu Nara Station, and the site where the temple used to be is in the vicinity of Nara VIVRE, a department store.

sen.j: この地は繁華街の騒音、振動等のため文化財の護持や宗教活動に支障があるとして、1984年から1985年にかけて圓證寺は現在地の生駒市に移転した。
sen.e: Since the noise and vibration pollution in this place from the downtown area would hinder the preservation of cultural properties and religious activities, Ensho-ji Temple was relocated to the current location in Ikoma City from 1984 to 1985.

Since the noise and vibration pollution that arose in the downtown area could hinder the preservation of cultural properties and religious activities in this place, Ensho-ji Temple was relocated to the current location in Ikoma City from 1984 to 1985.
sen.cmt: 意味をはっきりさせるよう、表現を少し直しました。
sen.e: Since the noise and vibration pollution that arose in the downtown area could hinder the preservation of cultural properties and religious activities in this place, Ensho-ji Temple was relocated to the current location in Ikoma City from 1984 to 1985.

sen.j: 室町時代建立の本堂と筒井順昭の供養塔である石造五輪塔（ともに重要文化財）も林小路から生駒市へ移建されている。
sen.e: The main hall built in the Muromachi period and the stone 'gorinto' tower (a gravestone composed of five pieces piled up one upon another) as a memorial tower for Junsho TSUTSUI (both of which are Important Cultural Properties), too, were relocated from Hayashikoji to Ikoma City and reconstructed there.

The main hall built in the Muromachi period and the stone 'gorinto' tower (a gravestone composed of five pieces piled up one upon another) as a memorial tower for Junsho TSUTSUI (both of which are Important Cultural Properties), too, were relocated from Hayashikoji to Ikoma City and reconstructed there.

The main hall built in the Muromachi period and the stone 'gorinto' tower (a gravestone composed of five pieces piled up one upon another) as a memorial tower for Junsho TSUTSUI (both of which are Important Cultural Properties), too, were relocated from Hayashikoji to Ikoma City and reconstructed there.

sen.j: 国指定文化財の建造物が寺自体の移転にともなって移築された例は比較的珍しい。
sen.e: It is relatively uncommon that cultural property buildings designated by the Japanese government were relocated and reconstructed at the time of the relocation of the temple.
It is relatively uncommon for the buildings designated cultural properties by the Japanese government to be relocated and reconstructed due to the relocation of the temple to which they belong.
sen.cmt: 意味をはっきりさせるよう、表現を少し直しました。
sen.e: It is relatively uncommon for the buildings designated cultural properties by the Japanese government to be relocated and reconstructed due to the relocation of the temple to which they belong.

sen.j: 室町時代末期の建立。
sen.e: The main hall was built at the end of the Muromachi period.
The main hall was built at the end of the Muromachi period.
The main hall was built at the end of the Muromachi period.

sen.j: 五輪塔（重要文化財）
sen.e: Gorinto tower (Important Cultural Property)
Gorinto tower (Important Cultural Property)

sen.j: 筒井順昭の供養塔。
sen.e: A memorial tower for Junsho TSUTSUI.
It is a memorial tower for Junsho TSUTSUI.
sen.cmt: It isを追加し、文とした。
sen.e: It is a memorial tower for Junsho TSUTSUI.

sen.j: 天文19年（1500年）の銘がある。
sen.e: The tower bears an inscription of the year 1500.
The tower bears an inscription that reads the year 1500.
sen.cmt: 意味をはっきりさせるよう、表現を少し直しました。
sen.e: The tower bears an inscription that reads the year 1500.

sen.j: 他に客殿至聖坊、雪山の庭（石庭）などがある。
sen.e: There also is a Shiseibo (literally, sacred lodgings) guest hall and Setsuzan-no-niwa garden (stone garden).
There are also the Shiseibo (literally, sacred lodgings) guest hall and Setsuzan-no-niwa garden (a stone garden).
There are also the Shiseibo (literally, sacred lodgings) guest hall and Setsuzan-no-niwa garden (a stone garden).

sen.j: 木造文殊菩薩騎獅像・普賢菩薩騎象像
sen.e: Wooden statue of Monju Bosatsu (Bodhisattva) riding on a lion and statue of Fugen Bosatsu (Bodhisattva) riding on an elephant
Wooden statue of Monju Bosatsu (Bodhisattva) riding on a lion and statue of Fugen Bosatsu (Bodhisattva) riding on an elephant
Wooden statue of Monju Bosatsu (Bodhisattva) riding on a lion and statue of Fugen Bosatsu (Bodhisattva) riding on an elephant

sen.j: 本尊の釈迦如来坐像（鎌倉時代）の脇侍として安置されているが、本尊像より古い平安時代の作である。
sen.e: Although these statues are enshrined as attendant figures for the principal image, Shaka Nyorai-zazo (sitting statue of Shakyamuni) (Kamakura period), they were produced earlier than the principal image during the Heian period.

Although these statues are enshrined as the attendant figures of the principal image, Shaka Nyorai-zazo (sitting statue of Shakyamuni) (Kamakura period), they were produced earlier than the principal image during the Heian period.

Although these statues are enshrined as the attendant figures of the principal image, Shaka Nyorai-zazo (sitting statue of Shakyamuni) (Kamakura period), they were produced earlier than the principal image during the Heian period.

sen.j: 文殊像と普賢像も必ずしも一具の像でなく、普賢像の方が時代的にやや古いようである。
sen.e: The Monju statue and the Fugen statue are not necessarily a complete set of statues, either, and the Fugen statue seems to be from a slightly earlier age.
The Monju statue and the Fugen statue may not be a complete set of statues, either, since the Fugen statue seems to be from the slightly earlier age.
sen.cmt: Necessarilyなどの言葉の使用に自然な印象を受けたので、若干表現を変えました。
sen.e: The Monju statue and the Fugen statue may not be a complete set of statues, either, since the Fugen statue seems to be from the slightly earlier age.

sen.j: 近鉄奈良線富雄駅よりバス「出垣内」下車。
sen.e: Take a bus from Kintetsu Nara Line, Tomio Station to 'Degaito' bus stop.
Take a bus at Tomio Station on Kintetsu Nara Line and get off at 'Degaito'.
